rev.diff:
Line 17: Line 17:
One of its most notable features is the creation of reversible [[Window (computing)|windows]]. This capability can be used for features like allowing the user to write notes and comments on the windows' backs, or displaying application dialogs without risking them being detached from the application they relate to. All windows start by looking like a normal [[2D computer graphics|2D]] or [[2.5D]] window, but can be manipulated as thin slate-like 3D objects which can be set at any angle or turned completely around by the user. Other features include provision of a panning virtual desktop, icons that reflect the live status of the window they represent and zooming of a window when it receives focus.
One of its most notable features is the creation of reversible [[Window (computing)|windows]]. This capability can be used for features like allowing the user to write notes and comments on the windows' backs, or displaying application dialogs without risking them being detached from the application they relate to. All windows start by looking like a normal [[2D computer graphics|2D]] or [[2.5D]] window, but can be manipulated as thin slate-like 3D objects which can be set at any angle or turned completely around by the user. Other features include provision of a panning virtual desktop, icons that reflect the live status of the window they represent and zooming of a window when it receives focus.
â
There is a [[LiveCD]] available from Project Looking Glass. The Looking Glass environment is also included on a LiveCD from the [[Granular Linux]] project.
+
There is a [[Live CD]] available from Project Looking Glass. The Looking Glass environment is also included on a Live CD from the [[Granular Linux]] project.
